string.text: These ammo parts can be reused for the creation of better variants. This is why some stalkers prefer to keep them around.\n \n
Torn sheets of silk coated paper. Even in a place like the Zone, it can be used for all kind of things. The cheapest way for packaging food or cleaning dirt.\n \n
Layered plastic based on fabric of fibers and polymeric binder (bakelite, polyester resin, epoxy resin). With proper skill it can be great help in repairing.\n \n
Simple cloth sheet, commonly used both to patch clothing and spread oils and cleaning solvents onto firearm mechanisms. Can be applied by any needle or glue.\n \n

Sheet of military-grade textile that can be used for field repairs of clothing and light armor. Valued for its relatively low price and high versatility, this material is commonly used by the Zoners. Medium-grade sewing equipment and advanced glue required for use. It can also be used to improve spread of liquids during weapon maintenance.\n \n

Thick textile patch reinforced with Kevlar padding. Can be used to repair medium and heavy armors. Large enough to cover multiple damaged areas. High quality sewing kits and adhesives are required to make use of it. Its alternative usage is weapon lubrication and cleaning - due to increased hardness it's able to reach less accessible areas of firearm parts.\n \n

Electric capacitors can store electricity. The simplest capacitor consists of two metal plates and a dielectric between them. It is a main component in most electrical devices due to its job in rectifying alternative current, storing electrical energy and bypassing noise. They are quite rare in the Zone, but are very useful.\n \n
A box of high-quality BJT transistors. A transistor consists of three Semiconductor parts (base, emitter, collector) that serve together to generate, convert and amplify electrical oscillations.\n \n

Resistors are the most common electronic components found in electronics. They limit and direct the passage of electrical current through circuit branches to ensure other components are getting proper voltage feeding. This box contains a good set of resistors with different resistance values and tolerance, ranging from 12 up to 82M ohms.\n \n

Electrotechnical copper wire is used in many devices to control the transmission or use of electric energy. In its pure form it is rare, but if necessary it can be easily extracted from common old radios, walkie-talkies and other electronics.\n \n
Pieces of wide-grained, light cedar wood. Mostly used for outdoor projects such as furniture, decks and tools. White it's not that useful in a place like the Zone, it could be used in crafting.\n \n

Handful of metal bits and pieces of equipment. A variety of many different types and grades of steel and aluminum alloys. Could be used to aid in repairing gear in the field, or perhaps even in crafting.\n \n

Handful of screws, washers, nuts, nails and small pieces of metallic plates. A variety of many different types and sizes. Could be used to aid in repairing gear in the field, or perhaps even in crafting.\n \n

A small pack made of low density polyethylene film. These thin plastic membranes are used to separate areas or volumes, hold items and act as barriers. Plastic films are used in a wide variety of applications. Despite being partly torn, polyethylene's characteristics makes it a great solution for packaging and isolating, especially for food and medicine.\n \n

The trigger mechanism and assembly from an unknown firearm. Most triggers are very similar, and there's no reason this one couldn't be shaved down to fit almost any weapon.
 
 %c[0,255,255,255]PROPERTIES:
 %c[d_cyan] • %c[ui_gray_2] basic material

A small spring from either the trigger assembly or inner workings of an unknown firearm. Could probably be adapted to replace most any small spring.
 
 %c[0,255,255,255]PROPERTIES:
 %c[d_cyan] • %c[ui_gray_2] basic material

Pistol grips from some unknown weapon. This rubberized handle could probably be shaped or molded to fit almost any firearm.
 
 %c[0,255,255,255]PROPERTIES:
 %c[d_cyan] • %c[ui_gray_2] basic material
Barrel from an 18.5mm cock double-barrel shotgun.\n \n
Barrel with an integrated silencer from an automatic special purpose 9mm rifle.\n \n
Barrel from a semi-automatic or automatic 7.62mm rifle.\n \n
Barrel from a 7.62mm rifle with a gas regulator.\n \n
Barrel from an automatic special purpose 9mm or PP rifle.\n \n
Barrel from the infamous or even legendary PPSh submachine gun system.\n \n
Double-mode Hammer Type Trigger. Designed for use in both automatic and single fire modes.\n \n
Triple-fire mode Hammer Type Trigger. Designed for use in automatic, single and double fire modes. Strongly tied to the design of the weapon.\n \n
Single-fire Mode Trigger Mechanism with Firing Pin (Trigger)
Single-fire mode trigger mechanism with firing pin.\n \n
Double-fire Mode Trigger Mechanism with Firing Pin (Trigger)
Double-fire mode trigger mechanism with firing pin. Allows shooting in single and automatic fire modes.\n \n
Trigger mechanism with hammer from a double-barrel shotgun.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with Turning Bolt Lock [R] (Carrier)
Sliding bolt carrier with a turning bolt lock, produced by Eastern manufacturers.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with Turning Bolt Lock [R] (Carrier)
Sliding bolt carrier with turning bolt lock, produced by Eastern manufacturers, from special automatic weapons.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with Turning Bolt Lock [NATO] (Carrier)
Longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn, produced by NATO, from a standard caliber automatic rifle.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with a Locking Bias (Carrier)
Sliding bolt carrier with a locking bias.\n \n
Half-free sliding bolt carrier with a roller brake.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with Locking Bolt (Carrier)
Sliding bolt carrier with locking bolt.\n \n
Lever-type Bolt Carrier with Locking Wedge (Carrier)
Lever type bolt carrier with locking wedge.\n \n
Sliding Bolt Carrier with Turning Bolt Lock [NATO] (Carrier)
Sliding bolt carrier with turning bolt lock; product of NATO countries, for a large-caliber automatic rifle.\n \n
Sliding free bolt carrier from a submachine gun.\n \n
Dropping-block breech from a smooth-bore shotgun or rifle with lever locking mechanism. In appearance, the ledges of the wedge are in good condition, without strong workings\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from a machine gun with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn. In appearance, locking heads are in good condition, without big signs of usage.\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from either automatic or semi-automatic smoothbore rifle, with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from a rifle with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with a locking bias and a longitudinally-sliding shutter with a "bolt" lock.\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from a rifle with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from a machine gun with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with four locks from a special automatic rifle with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with six locks from a machine gun with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with seven locks from a machine gun with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Rotating locking head with eight locks from a machine gun with a longitudinally-sliding breech block with lock turn.\n \n
Supercharger with Hammer from a Double-barrel Shotgun [R] (Bolt)
Right and left supercharger with hammer from a double-barrel shotgun.\n \n
Hammers from a Hammer-type Double-barrel Shotgun [R] (Bolt)
Right and left hammers from the double-barrelled horizontal shotgun.\n \n
Rotating locking head with two stops from a large-caliber automatic rifle produced by NATO countries, with a sliding bolt carrier with turning bolt lock.\n \n
Rotating locking head from either the PP or an automatic rifle with a longitudinal, half-free sliding bolt carrier.\n \n
Drummer with the mainspring from some domestic PP with a longitudinal sliding-free bolt carrier.\n \n
Drummer with the mainspring from some imported PP with a longitudinal, sliding-free bolt carrier.\n \n
Drummer with the mainspring from some Soviet PP, like the PP of Shpagin’s system with a longitudinal, sliding-free bolt carrier.\n \n
Gas tube from a smoothbore carbine.\n \n
mobile hand guard from pump-action shotgun.\n \n
Gas tube from a self-loading rifle.\n \n
Gas tube from a special automatic rifle. 9mm.\n \n
Gas tube from a semi-automatic or automatic rifle (Russia).\n \n
Gas tube from a semi-automatic or automatic rifle (NATO).\n \n
Gas tube from a machine gun.\n \n
Ejector from a rifle with a sliding bolt carrier with locking bolt.\n \n
Ejector from Over-under Double-barrel Shotgun [R] (Gas Tube)
Ejector (extractor) from an over-under double barrel shotgun.\n \n
Ejector from Over-under Double-barrel Shotgun [R] (Gas Tube)
Ejector from an over-under double barrel shotgun.\n \n
Gas tube from the MP5 submachine gun with a handle.\n \n

The very base of an outfit. These sheets are made of different materials such as cotton, polycotton, wool and leather to provide comfort and durability. Other protective fabrics are used like rubber and ballistic nylon, along with joint protections and a set of hardware and zippers.\n \n

The very base of an outfit. These textiles are blended with synthetic materials such as polyester and lycra to provide versatility and durability. Other protective fabrics are used like rubber and ballistic nylon, along with joint protections and a set of hardware and zippers.\n \n

These sheets are made of different materials such as polyester, leather and canvas, including a set of hardware and zippers. Good durability in harsh environmental conditions, which is why such materials are suitable for traveling even inside the Zone.\n \n

Sheets of military-grade textiles are often used for field clothing and light armor. Valued for its relatively low price and high versatility, this material is commonly used by the Zoners. Other protective fabrics are used like rubber and ballistic nylon, along with joint protections and a set of hardware and zippers.\n \n

These textiles are more resistant to fire through chemical treatment or manufactured fireproof fibers. In the Zone, such fabrics are commonly used in outfits to provide protection against hazardous environments and flame-based anomalies such as the Burner and Comet.\n \n

These textiles are more resistant to electric shock and chemical particles through chemical treatment or manufactured fibers. In the Zone, such fabrics are commonly used in outfits to provide protection against hazardous environments and chemical/shock-based anomalies such as the Electro and Fruit Punch.\n \n
Rigid Polyvinyl Chloride (RPVC) is a non-flammable material that is resistant to weathering. RPVC can also be UV stabilized to provide higher protection against anomalous hazards.\n \n
Rigid Polyvinyl Chloride (RPVC) is a non-flammable material that is resistant to weathering. RPVC can also be UV stabilized to provide higher protection against anomalous hazards.\n \n
A tough and durable PVC coated polyester and rubber-fibre fabric designed for use in providing protection against hazards. It can be sewn, glued or welded.\n \n
A tough and durable PVC coated polyester and carbon-fibre fabric designed for use in providing protection against hazards. It can be sewn, glued or welded.\n \n
This magnesium grid acts as dielectric layers to protect the outfit and its wearer from powerful electric shocks and psi-waves. It can also offer protection against other hazards.\n \n
This magnesium grid acts as dielectric layers to protect the outfit and it's wearer from powerful electric shocks and psi-waves. It can also offer protection against other hazards.\n \n

The thermal degradation behaviour of bismuth-sulfate makes it a great choice for outfits used inside the Zone. Usually coated on polymer sheets for considerable body coverage. It can provide protection against environmental hazards.\n \n

The thermal degradation behaviour of barium-sulfate makes it a great choice for outfits used inside the Zone. Usually coated on polymer sheets for considerable body coverage. It can provide protection against environmental hazards.\n \n

Multilayer Aluminized fabrics are specifically designed for protective apparel and shields used in environments that pose serious fire risk or safety hazards associated with radiant heat and chemical sources. In addition, these fabrics offer great isolatation against psi-waves effects.\n \n

Multilayer Aluminized fiberglass fabrics are specifically designed for protective apparel and shields used in environments that pose serious shock risk or safety hazards associated with radiant heat and chemical sources. In addition, these fabrics offer great isolatation against psi-waves effects.\n \n

PBI-blended fabrics have been trusted in the fire service over the years. Recognized as the leading high-performance protective fire resistant fabrics. For this reason, Zoners took advantage of these fabrics for their own outfits.\n \n

PBI-blended fabrics have been trusted in the fire service over the years. Recognized as the leading high-performance protective fire resistant fabrics. For this reason, Zoners took advantage of these fabrics for their own outfits.\n \n

Originally developed for use in chemical warfare suits. Activated Carbon Cloth has many relevant uses in defense, industrial, and medical applications. It considerably enhances the efficacy of both advanced and active wound dressings, along with providing great protection from radiation particles.\n \n

Originally developed for use in chemical warfare suits. Activated Carbon Cloth now has many relevant uses in defense, industrial, and medical applications. It considerably enhances the efficacy of both advanced and active wound dressings, along with providing great protection from radiation particles.\n \n

Inserts made of constantan sheets acting as dielectric layers to protect the outfit and its wearer from electric shocks, psi-waves and radioactive materials. It can also offer protection against other hazards, which is why they found their use inside the Zone.\n \n
Insulating Constantan Inserts w/ Fiberglass Coating

Inserts made of constantan sheets and fiberglass-coated fabrics. They acts as dielectric layers to protect the outfit and its wearer from electric shocks, psi-waves and radioactive materials. It can also offer protection against other hazards, which is why they found their use inside the Zone.\n \n

High temperature resistant fabrics woven from “E" glass fibers and coated with Vermiculite based film providing extended service temperatures up to 1500°F and good shock resistance up to 20Kv. In a place like the Zone, these fabrics can come in handy against anomalous hazards.\n \n

High temperature resistant fabrics woven from “E" glass fibers and coated with Vermiculite based film providing extended service temperatures up to 1700°F and good shock resistance up to 25Kv. In a place like the Zone, these fabrics can come in handy against anomalous hazards.\n \n
Kevlar K129 Plates w/ Reinforced Ceramic Inserts

Kevlar plates are widely known for their protective capabilities and are highly valued because of this feature. They perform a wide variety of functions, the most important of which is absorbing the impact of firearm projectiles on the front and back of the torso. They constitute a lightweight alternative to heavy steel plates. Additionally, any type of armor plating also helps maintain suits condition, preventing degradation through wear and tear. Used by military units around the world.\n \n
Kevlar Protera Plates w/ Reinforced Ceramic Inserts

Kevlar plates are widely known for their protective capabilities and are highly valued because of this feature. They perform a wide variety of functions, the most important of which is absorbing the impact of firearm projectiles on the front and back of the torso. They constitute a lightweight alternative to heavy steel plates. Additionally, any type of armor plating also helps maintain suits condition, preventing degradation through wear and tear. Used by military units around the world.\n \n

They constitute a lightweight alternative to heavy steel plates. Additionally, any type of armor plating also helps maintain suits condition, preventing degradation through wear and tear. Used by military units around the world.\n \n

Grade-B polyethylene Plates w/ Expanded Carrier

Polyethylene plates that provide extra protection to vital areas. These hard armor plates have proven effective against all handgun bullets and a range of rifles. These upgraded ballistic vests have become standard in military use, as soft body armor vests are ineffective against military rifle rounds.\n \n
Grade-A Polyethylene Plates w/ Expanded Carrier

These upgraded ballistic vests have become standard in military use, as soft body armor vests are ineffective against military rifle rounds.\n \n

Carbon Nanotube Layers w/ Kevlar-49 Fabrics

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have great potential applications in making ballistic-resistance materials. The remarkable properties of CNTs makes them an ideal candidate for reinforcing polymers and other materials and is often used in applications such as bullet-proof vests.\n \n
Carbon Nanotube Layers w/ Kevlar-29 Fabrics (Reinforced)

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have great potential applications in making ballistic-resistance materials. The remarkable properties of CNTs makes them an ideal candidate for reinforcing polymers and other materials and is often used in applications such as bullet-proof vests.\n \n
Polyethylene Fibre Layers w/ Polycarbonate Inserts

Polyethylene plates that provide extra protection to vital areas. These hard armor plates have proven effective against all handgun bullets and a range of rifles. These upgraded ballistic vests have become standard in military use, as soft body armor vests are ineffective against military rifle rounds.\n \n

Polyethylene plates that provide extra protection to vital areas. These hard armor plates have proven effective against all handgun bullets and a range of rifles. These upgraded ballistic vests have become standard in military use, as soft body armor vests are ineffective against military rifle rounds.\n \n

As compared to Kevlar material carbon-fibre is little different and is not very effective against the sharp materials. But the advantage of carbon-fibre is that it can stand high temperatures while Kevlar starts to weaken in this area. The materials made of carbon-fibre tend to be light, therefore it offers more flexibility.\n \n

As compared to Kevlar material carbon-fibre is little different and is not very effective against the sharp materials. But the advantage of carbon-fibre is that it can stand high temperatures while Kevlar starts to weaken in this area. The materials made of carbon-fibre tend to be light, therefore it offers more flexibility.\n \n
Mechanical frame powered by a system of electric motors, pneumatics, levers and hydraulics that give the wearer both superior protection as well as greatly increased physical strength.\n \n
